Next, all four plates are connected to ground and a small hole is drilled through the center of each plate. All four plates are then disconnected from ground and repositioned as in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. Charge is then added to the plates, resulting in electric fields between adjacent pairs of plates with directions and magnitudes as indicated in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. Assume that the holes do not affect the electric field.A charged particle is released from rest immediately to the right of the hole in Plate <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The particle has mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and a positive charge <math alttext="positive lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></math>. Initially, the particle accelerates to the right, toward the hole in Plate <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, due to the electric field between plates <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The particle passes between plates <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> into the region between plates <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> and <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. The particle either comes to an instantaneous stop before reaching the hole in Plate <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, OR reaches the hole in Plate <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>.(b) As appropriate, derive an expression for either the distance from Plate <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> at which the particle comes to an instantaneous stop OR the kinetic energy of the particle when it reaches the hole in Plate <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, <math alttext="E sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the particle’s speed as a function of position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> in the region <math alttext="0 less than x, less than 4 D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>D</mi></math>, which covers both the region between plates <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and the region inside the hole of Plate <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

(d) Indicate whether the graph you drew in part (c) is consistent or inconsistent with the electric field between plates <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> shown in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. Justify your claim that the graph and the electric field are either consistent or not consistent.
